We know the universe is expanding from analysing the light we recieve from distant galaxies. Light sources that are moving away from us are "red-shifted" ie distorted towards the red end of the spectrum. If they were moving towards us they would be "blue-shifted", it's the same effect you observe when a car goes past you and the noise of its engine changes, but with light waves not sound waves.
 
 Some complicted maths related to the apparent brightness of distant supernovae suggests that indeed the expansion is accelerating, however no one actually knows what could be causing this. One idea is Einstein's "cosmological constant", a force he invented to balance his own equations that showed the universe would collapse under its own gravity. (This was back when everyone 'knew' that the universe was static and neither expanding or contracting).
 Another idea is the mysterious "dark energy" that scientists believe makes up about 70% of the universe. Again, no one knows what this is, "dark energy" is just the name for something out there that has to exist in order for galaxies to behave the way they do; they move as if they contain far more matter than we can see. Scientists think (and have very recently begun to prove) that the universe is about 4% ordinary matter like the earth, the sun etc, 23% "dark matter" which is an exotic form of matter mostly found between galaxies, and 73% dark energy.
 
 According to (pretty much speculative) theory, dark energy exerts a negative pressure on the universe, much like Einstein's cosmological constant, counteracting and overcoming gravity, causing it to expand. I have just read Brian Greene's fantastic book "The Fabric of the Cosmos" and interestingly, he says that recent observations suggest that the rate of expansion has changed more than once: expansion accelerated for the first few billion years of the universe, then decelerated for a few billion years, then started accelerating again. But no one knows why. Weird, huh?
 
 Unfortunately, you're asking something that the cutting edge of physics is only beginning to probe. I can recommend Greene's book though, it explains in comprehensible terms pretty much everything we know and was published in 2004 so is pretty much up to date.

The equations used to calculate the speed of "receeding" galaxies are dopler effect equations. At the base assumption, they assume that the speed of light is continuous. If it is discontinuous then whole spaces of time might be longer. Whole distances might change.
 
 Here is a cheezy example with a simple equation. RT=D where R=Rate, T=Time and D=Distance. If the rate is 5m/s and the time is 100 Seconds then the distance is 500 meters. Now assume that the speed is 4m/s for 10 seconds and 3m/s for 50 seconds and 5m/s for 40 seconds. Then the distance computed would be 40 meters + 150 meters + 200 meters for a total of 390 meters. It still traveled for 100 seconds but the speed is "discontinuous". It changes the distance something travelled. The doppler effect is a little more complicated but not that much. It is essentially calculating the speed of the distant object in relation to the local object (Einstein's relativity). There are equations that calculate the wavelength of light (the color) based on the frequency and the time. Lambda=frequency multiplied by time.
